cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

EXPRESS MAIL STEAMERS
FROM
ALEXANDRIA, PORT SAID, AND SUEZ,
TO
NAPLES, MARSEILLES,
GENOA, SOUTHAMPTON, ANTWERP,
BREMEN, HAMBURG, AMERICA,
EASTERN ASIA, AUSTRALIA Etc.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. “Oruba" will leave Suez about October 5
R.M.S "Ophir" will leave Suez about October 19.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Ortona" will leave Port Said October 23
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Port Said October 8
Passengers returning by the Line obtain one-third rebate off the above fares if leaving England before the end of October.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-906

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES MAY TO OCTOBER.
Port Said to Tilbury £ 12.15.0. and Port Said to Marseilles £ 9.0.0.
Passengers returning by the Line will be granted a rebate of 33% off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £ 11.6.8. and Marseilles to Port Said £ 8.0.0.
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, RANGOON. Departure from Suez.
S.S. Herefordshire 7182 tons, Oct. 11.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Cheshire 5,775 tons, October 1.
Agents– Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO’s LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. RANGOON 6000 Tons will leave PORT SAID about July 23 for London.
S.S. BURMA 5600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 6 for London.
S.S. ARRACAN 5800 Tons will leave PORT SAID about August 20 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

GENERAL RAILWAY AND STEAMSHIP AGENTS. BANKERS.
BAGGAGE AND FORWARDING AGENTS.
Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.
FREIGHT SERVICE, Steamers leave Cairo every Saturday and Tuesday for Assouan and Halfa.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT, Lowest Rates.
Best camp equipment in the country! 10 12-904

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,340,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s’occupe de l’achat et de la vente d'effets sur l’Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d’Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d’un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d’un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 28337-10-8-907

Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m. and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.p: For Infants, Benger's Food solves the problem of hand-rearing. It contains all the elements necessary to healthy development in infancy.
For Invalids there is no food like Benger's Food. It assists nature in restoring the system to complete health.
For the Aged, Benger's Food is particularly adapted to the enfeebled digestion of advancing years.
For those who are well, Benger's Food is an ideal light meal, dainty and nutritive.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.

The Egyptian Gazette THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER. ESTABLISHED 1830. Editor und Kanagar . • R. SNELLING Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFB. - SATURDAY, OCTOBER 20, 1906 THE METRIC SYSTEM According to Reuter's telegram of Thursday, the adoption of the metric Nystem by the firm of Messrs. Kynoch Limited, of whose board Mr. Arthur Chamberlain is chairman, has fallen as a bomb upon the commercial world of Great Britain. Mr. Chamberlain expresses the opinion that the firm is only anticipating general reformation which must soon come in England, and mys that they are thereby reducing the cost of their calculations and in creasing their export trade. The telegram, however, does not make clear to what ettent the metric system (in the literal and original meaning of the word "metric") has been adopted. A few years ago "metric" system was suggested with an inch unit as basis, and we remain in ignorance as to whether the firm has adopted the inch or the metre unit. No worse method for weighing and measuring than the one which has held sway in England for centuries could be conceived, and scientists were long since compelled to discard it and base all their calculations upon the infinitely more rational metric system. That system has stood the test of use satisfactorily, whereas ours has proved most clumsy and detrimental to our trade with foreign countries. The general adoption of the metric system into our country could be effected with very little cost and labour were the inch to be taken as the unit of length, but the entire changing of the inch unit would be very costly and a great obstrue. tion to the introduction of the more scientific system. Assuming, therefore, that we are about to adopt the metric system, which we should have done very many years ago.--the question still remains, what shall we take as our unit ! A uniformity of systems and units would greatly simplity interchange of trade between us and other countries, but can it be obtained? There are indeed two methods by which such a consommation could be reached. The first, and the one to which we incline the more readily, is that the inch unit should be adopted in the metric system, and that the some 550,000,000 people who use it should force the 150,000,000 people who use the metre unit to adopt the former. The second method is the adoption of the metre as a length unit by Greater Britain, which would be a terrific sacrifice. It is not the adoption of the metrie system which would prove a diffi culty, but the adoption of the metre length unit. The clumsinesss and impractibility of our systems of calculations are universally recognised, and reform is, therefore, greatly to be desired, but we would hardly counsel the adoption of the metre unit. A nation who divides a square pole into thirty and a quarter square yards, who follows such a system of recording temperatures, the bare mention of which makes a scientist shud. nder, indeed whose every mathematical calcula. tion is ridiculously laborious, must be content to run an uneven race. It behoves us, there. fore, to adopt the general decimal system used by other countries. Up to 1897 the irregular and arbitrary nature of the British standards was enforced by law, but in August of that year Parlia ment sanctioned the use of the metric system, which up to the present no British firm has been sufficiently courageous to adopt. In the metrie system there are five principal units, those of length, ares, volume, capacity, and weight. The unit of length is the metre; the unit of area is the square metre; the unit of volume is the cubic metre; the unit of capacity is the litre, which is one-tenth of a metre ; and the unit of weight is a gram, i.e. the weight of water contained in one-thousandth of litre. Such is the system which we ought to adopt, with the exception that the inch should take the place of the metre. The whole system is based upon a single measurement of length and from it we can find out by simple calculation the weight of known volumes of different substances. But the English system has the dis advantage of being variable as well as arbitrary, as is instanced by the existence of two hundred different weights for weighing corn, as an example of which we might note that 46 Sutherland pounds of an equal 240 Cornish pounds. Lord Kelvin denounced the English system as time wasting and brain-destroying in its confusions, and we heartily agree with him. These are not the only disadvantages, Many firms have to spend hundreds of pounds year in the necessary transcription of English weights and measures to the metrical system mnd vice versá, and, moreover, England is continually losing orders owing to her bad system, In many,and probably in the majority of cases, the prices of competing firms differ very little, and the question of convenience invulved in che use or non-use of the metric system may easily decide who gets the order. KAMEL'S INCORRUPTIBILITY. REPLY TO "AL MOKATTAM.".
Re the pleasant tales that have been going Ibn about as to the diminution of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's mlary we bote the following paragraph are e in the "Lewa" : The nation koows the political opinions of "Al Lewa," and all are aware that its from director is not one to refrain from expend mem! iture drawn from his capital or his profite healt Had he received pecuniary assistance from any quarter he would have said so, but be works for his country and not for himself. We have nothing but soorn for the base insinuations." Sancta simplicitas! lo reference to the above, we have this morning received the following telogram from Mustapba Pasba Kamel :I entirely contradict what "Al Mokattam" ITE stated to the effoot that."Al Lewa" draws a by ar salary or any fondoial support from Tarkoy | Pod on any other country. "Al Lewa" is a wholly leave independent paper, and it is impossible for any person to ascertain the contrary. "Al Mokattam's" versions about the nativo Egyptians are entirely opfounded and not 25th worth to be qaoted in the esteemed papers, MUSTAPHA KAXEL noad ol-K 30th NATIVE PRESS ON MR. BLUNT. Ales "Al Watan" says : No one has yet oriticised Lord Cromer like this original Bogliabman, the A fevered eccentrio, Mr. Wilfred Blont. No one with bas attacked bim with soch violence and vigour. I will Some Egyptians regard Mr. Blant as an intellectual phenomenon. The majority regard him as an oddity, and as being incapable of giving any advice that can be accepted with profit. The batred and malice of this strange personage have led him at last to write an article to the Figaro" containing a scandalous ber. personal attack on Lord Cromer. Tbe latter, ope! according to Mr. Blant, bas always aimed at and annexation by devious and unworthy intrigue. five Our readers can be trusted to form their own opinion of this writer. He is simply ad eccentric, for whose opinions and literary productions merit tipe Do consideration wbatever. The very extravag | anoe of his opslaaghts can only be of ad vantage to Lord Cromer, who returns to Egypt stronger than before. sont THE KÄEDIVE Yesterday evening the Kbedive beld . reception at Ras el-Tin Palace on the occasion of the beginning of the month of Ramadan. Ball Lood JANE HADING'S VISIT. Ottod Mme Jane Hading will give her first repre legal the sentation at Alexandria on the 13th of Novem. ber, and on the 17th of that month she will Agr open at Cairo, where six plays will be staged, Th and she will then return hore to give another brand five representations, from November 23 to 87, ratei inclusive. On the 28th November sbo will los vo pori for Smyrds, and will afterwards visit Constantinople and Romania. Her oompsoy consists tion of well-known Prenoh artistes from tha Odoon, Phot Gymnasium, and Sarah Berpbardt theatree. Vion and ti P M of dien FREEMASONRY. lear At the meeting of the "Quatuor Coronati Lodge," No. 2876, beld in London on the 5th M. ins!, Bro. Joseph Sakskini Boy was unanim-bap! ously elected member of that Lodgo. Wo Cain congratalate Sakakini Bay on his nomination, which is a tribute to bio popularity m . mason. A Dow masopio lodge, eslled "El Radja," hne been formed in Cairo, under the auspices of the Grand Lodge of Jerusalem. The W. M. is Constantin Bey Capello. ESBEKIEH GARDENS THEATRE. "LA DAMB DB CHEZ MAXIM." This well-known farcica! oomedy was given last night to a well-filled house and provod. great attraction. It is an extremely fanny play, the situation at times being very cleverly arranged, though in some CHAOS somewhat wb risquée, and might not be appreciated by an car Eoglish aodience. All the same everybody fee neamed bigbly pleased with the piece, and the audience went away in the best of bomours. We must oonfoss to having bad some doubts as to the Gardet company being op to the average, jodging from a visit we paid to this theatre shortly after their arrival, but we have no hesitation in saying that the company last night showed vast improvement on the previous efforts, besides being strengthened by the addi. tion of a most valuable recruit in the person of Mlle. Berthe Chantepay, who is a host in berself. She actod and sang admirably throughout, ber impersonation of the leading part being well nigh perfect. She favoured us with . couple of songs doring the segond not which called forth loud applause, though we are oortain that half the audience did not grasp the meaning of the se sond one, consisting mostly of Parisian slang; albeit it appeared to groatly am use those who onderstood. Apart from Mme. Bellanger, M. Smits, and M. Lacroix, all of wbom oontributed to tbo 80008ns of the piece, Dot mach oan be said of the rest, who were only moderately good. OBITUARY.
MAITRE ZAJA
We regret to announce the death of Maltro Zoja, formerly bâtonnier of the Mized Bar at Aloxandria Boat At the opening of the sitting this morning Affair at the Mixed Civil Court, ander the prooidonoy Barope of Judge Pangalou, Maitre Avlonitio mado ao ou logistio sposob on the merits of the deconsod. Mas Judge Psogalos roplied on bobslf of the Bench in sympathetic terms. | Вагоре The RENE CARTON DB WIART. on the Wo ghostly rogret to learn of the death of|(Count Mr. René Carton de Wiart, governor of Tourb of Sir prison, which has taken place at Naplo. Mr. Birch Roué de Wiart was only 39 years of ago, and winter during his many years of Govord mont sorvion in this country be made himself very popular Min with all communition Ho served in the Belgian bn be army previous to coming to Egypt, wbere be Beypti ww first an officer of the mounted polico. Porto-mon bio Beyptian services the Khedivo conferred appoin opon bim the orders of the Osmanieh and the decide Madjidieb, sod he recently reobivad too decoration of Chevalier of the Order of Leopold. Mr. Mr. Réno do Wiart will be greatly missed in l of Bu Cairo, where his circle of friends was very Marae wido.
